events.title: Birth
events.summary: Muzio Filippo Vincenzo Francesco Saverio Clementi was born in Rome, Papal States, being the eldest of seven children in his family. His musical talent was recognized early on by his father, leading to private musical instruction.
events.fun_version: Muzio Filippo Vincenzo Francesco Saverio Clementi, born in Rome, Papal States, was the eldest of seven musical prodigies in his family. His father recognized his musical talent early on and enrolled him in private music lessons, showing us that being a piano prodigy is about hitting the right keys before your six siblings catch up!

events.title: Early Compositions
events.summary: By the age of 13, Clementi had already composed an oratorio and a mass, showcasing his early talent in composition.
events.fun_version: At just 13, Clementi wasn’t playing video games like his peers—he was busy composing an oratorio and a mass! Someone get this kid a tuxedo and a conductor's baton; he’s a prodigy in the making!

events.title: Move to England
events.summary: Clementi moved to England in 1766 after being taken to the estate of Sir Peter Beckford, where he lived and studied while providing musical entertainment.
events.fun_version: In 1766, Clementi packed his bags and put on his fanciest powdered wig, ready to conquer England. After arriving at Sir Peter Beckford's estate, he lived and studied diligently while discovering that playing music was the best way to charm wealthy people and avoid awkward small talk at dinner parties!

events.title: Organist Position
events.summary: At the age of 14, Clementi became the organist of the parish church of San Lorenzo in Damaso, marking an important step in his musical career.
events.fun_version: At the tender age of 14, Clementi took on the role of organist at the parish church of San Lorenzo in Damaso, marking an important step in his musical career. Who wouldn’t trust a teenager with a gigantic instrument right by the altar?

events.title: First Public Performance
events.summary: In 1770, Clementi made his first public performance as an organist, which impressed the audience and marked the beginning of his successful concert pianist career.
events.fun_version: In 1770, Clementi made his first public performance as an organist while tickling the ivories. The audience was so impressed that they forgot to ask him to play 'Chopsticks' for the next hour. This marked the beginning of his career as a concert pianist, where every key he pressed felt like a tiny miracle.

events.title: Harpsichordist Beneficiary Concert
events.summary: Clementi made his first appearance as a harpsichordist in a benefit concert on 3 April 1775, after moving to London in 1774.
events.fun_version: On 3 April 1775, Clementi made his first appearance as a harpsichordist, probably wondering if he time-traveled from the 18th-century baroque disco! No, it's not a dance party; it's a benefit concert, and he, the star, is about to make harpsichord history!

events.title: European Tour
events.summary: Clementi began a three-year European tour in 1780, which included performances in major cities such as Paris and Vienna, showcasing his skill to significant audiences.
events.fun_version: In 1780, Clementi embarked on a European tour lasting three years! He showcased his skill to significant audiences in major cities like Paris and Vienna, proving that the piano isn't just for playing 'Chopsticks' at family gatherings but can actually impress crowds!

events.title: Musical Contest with Mozart
events.summary: Clementi agreed to a musical contest with Mozart in Vienna for the Holy Roman Emperor, which ended in a declared tie, highlighting his prominence as a composer.
events.fun_version: Clementi and Mozart walked into Vienna for a music showdown for the Holy Roman Emperor. With notes flying and pianos battling, they ended in a tie! It's hard to pick a winner when both are composing legends and Clementi is seriously establishing his prominence!

events.title: Teaching Career
events.summary: Beginning in 1783, Clementi dedicated around twenty years to performing, conducting, and teaching music in England, influencing many notable students.
events.fun_version: Clementi kicked off his musical career in 1783 and spent the next twenty years juggling performances, conducting, and teaching music in England, influencing many notable students!

events.title: Founding of Philharmonic Society
events.summary: On 24 January 1813, Clementi co-founded the Philharmonic Society of London, which later became the Royal Philharmonic Society, emphasizing his continued influence on music.
events.fun_version: On 24 January 1813, Clementi co-founded the Philharmonic Society of London, forever changing the course of music and highlighting his continued influence. This society eventually morphed into the Royal Philharmonic Society, proving that good things truly take time—like an orchestra hitting the right notes!

events.title: Final Public Appearance
events.summary: Clementi made his last public appearance at the opening concert of the Philharmonic Society in 1828, marking the end of his performing career.
events.fun_version: Clementi decided to call it quits after his grand finale at the Philharmonic Society's opening concert in 1828, marking the end of his performing career—apparently, even piano maestros need to retire before they start sounding like broken records!

events.title: Death
events.summary: Clementi died on 10 March 1832, after a short illness, and was buried in the cloisters of Westminster Abbey, ending his long and influential life in music.
events.fun_version: Clementi died on 10 March 1832 after a short illness and was buried in the cloisters of Westminster Abbey, which has improved acoustics compared to his last concert, ending his long and influential life in music.

works.title: 5 Piano Sonatas and a Duet, Op.1a
Piano Duet, 2 Sonatas and 3 Fugues, Op.6
12 Waltzes for Piano, Tambourine and Triangle, Op.38
12 Waltzes for Piano, Tambourine and Triangle, Op.39
Fantasie avec variations sur l'air 'Au clair de la lune', Op.48
